perturbation.original_text: Application Provider will remove any advertising from Application Provider's listed competitors displayed on the Co-Branded Pages.
perturbation.changed_text: Application Provider will attempt to remove any advertising from Application Provider's listed competitors displayed on the Co-Branded Pages within 30 business days.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract states a strict deadline of three business days, this introduces uncertainty and possible delays, potentially harming Excite@Home. This delay in removing competitor ads can lead to a breach of duty of good faith and fair dealing, as Excite@Home's competitive interests are being actively harmed during this extended period. Courts generally consider adherence to explicitly agreed-upon deadlines as part of fulfilling the duty of good faith.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: Within three business days of receiving Excite@Home's written update, Application Provider will remove any advertising from Excite@Home's listed competitors displayed on the Co-Branded Pages.
perturbation.changed_text: Application Provider will use commercially reasonable efforts to remove advertising from Excite@Home's listed competitors displayed on the Co-Branded Pages.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract states a strict deadline of three business days for Application Provider to remove ads of Excite@Home's competitors. By changing the language to 'commercially reasonable efforts,' the contract introduces ambiguity and weakens Application Provider's obligation. 'Commercially reasonable efforts' is a vague standard that can be interpreted in many ways, potentially allowing Application Provider to delay or avoid removing competitor ads altogether.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: Application Provider shall: i) Ensure that future emails to the Program Member do not contain any Excite@Home branding; and ii) Ensure that future emails do not direct the Program Member to the Co-Branded Application. Application Provider may continue to direct Program Members to http://www.e-centives.com or its subsequent replacement.
perturbation.changed_text: Application Provider may, at its discretion: i) endeavor to remove Excite@Home branding from future emails to the Program Member when technically feasible; and ii) generally attempt to avoid directing the Program Member to the Co-Branded Application where practical. Application Provider may continue to direct Program Members to http://www.e-centives.com or its subsequent replacement.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandates specific actions, while the changed clause introduces ambiguity and discretion. This change introduces uncertainty and weakens the protection for Excite@Home's brand and service, potentially harming its reputation and customer relationships. By making compliance discretionary, the changes undermine the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing, which requires parties to act honestly and reasonably in performing their contractual obligations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
